questions.question: A 62-year-old woman presents with a protruding mass from her vagina and difficulty urinating. Physical examination reveals third-degree uterine prolapse with an ulcerated area on the prolapsed tissue as shown in the image. Which of the following correctly describes the cause of the ulcerated area and the appropriate management for this condition? corticosteroids. intervention.

options.A: Ulcer occurs due to infection; management includes antibiotics and surgical intervention.
options.B: Ulcer occurs due to repeated friction; management includes local wound care and topical
options.C: Ulcer occurs due to allergic reactions; management includes antihistaminics and surgical
options.D: Ulcer occurs due to venous congestion; management includes antiseptic and hygroscopic packing.

questions.explanation: hygroscopic packing. Correct answer: D Explanation: Prolapsed uterine tissue develops decubitus ulcers mainly as a result of venous congestion and should be managed primarily with local wound care using antiseptics and hygroscopic packing. Decubitus ulcer secondary to prolapse: A trophic ulcer, found at the dependent part of the prolapsed mass

questions.question: All of the following are true regarding the usage of pessary in a prolapse patient except?

options.A: Are a non-surgical option for managing pelvic organ prolapse.
options.B: Can be used as a temporary measure before surgical intervention.
options.C: Regular follow-up is not required once a pessary is adequately fitted.
options.D: Pessaries can be used to treat stress urinary incontinence.

questions.explanation: Correct answer: C Explanation: Vaginal pessary: Types Ring Pessary, Gellhorn Pessary, Donut Pessary. Mechanism Provides mechanical support to the pelvic organs Helps with urinary and bowel symptoms Conditions Patients with complications (stress urinary incontinence, combined prolapse) (Option D) Non-surgical management for inoperable cases (Option A) Patients awaiting surgery (temporary relief) (Option B) Prolapse in a pregnant female. Disadvantages Vaginal irritation, discharge, infection. Pressure necrosis Regular follow-up (Option C) Contraindications Active pelvic infection Allergic reaction to material Non-compliance with follow-up Checking adequate retention of pessary: One finger can be inserted between the vaginal side wall & edge of the pessary Pessary should not descent down till introitus VALSALVA / COUGH: Some descent of pessary is expected but it should return to its normal position. Reference: Williams Gynaecology (4th Edition), page 547-549.

questions.question: A 34-year-old reproductive-age female presents with significant uterine prolapse and expresses concerns about future childbearing. Which surgical management option is most appropriate in this case?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Sling surgery Explanation: Sling surgery , such as a uterosacral or sacrospinous ligament suspension with mesh, provides effective support to the uterus while preserving fertility, suitable for reproductive-age women concerned about future childbearing. Sling Surgery for Uterine Prolapse: Indications: Symptomatic uterine prolapse (heaviness, bulging, urinary symptoms). Women whose childbearing is incomplete. Types: Dynamic Sling Uses materials allowing for some movement and flexibility. Eg: Purandare sling Static Sling Utilizes non-flexible materials providing rigid support. Eg:Shirodkar sling and Khanna sling Composite Combines elements of both dynamic and static slings Eg: Virkud sling Sling surgery: Anterior attachment : Pubocervical fascia (supports the bladder and anterior vaginal wall). Posterior attachment : Sacrospinous ligament (supports posterior vaginal wall). Vaginal hysterectomy (Option A) addresses uterine prolapse effectively, it is not the preferred option for reproductive-age women seeking to preserve their fertility. Sacrocolpopexy (Option B) is commonly used for vault prolapse after hysterectomy. Fothergill's repair (Option C) (not routinely performed) can be performed in women who have completed childbearing. Reference: Uterine Prolapse

questions.question: A 62-year-old woman presents with a sensation of a bulge in her vaginal area, which worsens on straining. On examination, a protrusion of the vaginal apex beyond the hymen is noted. There is no associated urinary incontinence. What is the most appropriate management for this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Vaginal hysterectomy and uterosacral suspension Explanation: Vaginal hysterectomy, along with uterosacral suspension, which treat prolapse and support the vaginal apex, respectively, are preferred in post-menopausal women presenting with vault prolapse. Treatment options for vault prolapse in females: Treatment Option Indications Conservative (pelvic floor exercises) (Option A) Mild prolapse, asymptomatic, patient preference Pessary fitting (Option B) Symptomatic prolapse, desire for non-surgical management in mild to moderate cases. Vaginal hysterectomy and uterosacral suspension Significant prolapse, symptomatic, desire for definitive surgical correction McCall culdoplasty (Option D) Significant posterior vaginal wall prolapse, desire for surgical repair in which preservation of the uterus is desired. Sacrocolpopexy Severe prolapse, previous failed repairs, desire for durable support Colpocleisis Elderly or frail patients, desire for definitive closure of the vagina Reference: Williams Gynaecology (4th Edition), page 547-551.

questions.question: Identify the following and its usage in obstetrics and gynecology.

options.A: Device used to monitor fetal heart rate during labour
options.B: Contraceptive device inserted into the uterus
options.C: Support device used to manage pelvic organ prolapse
options.D: Tool for inducing labour contractions during childbirth

questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Support device used to manage pelvic organ prolapse Explanation: Ring pessary is a supporting device used for managing the symptoms of pelvic organ prolapse. Ring Pessary (Doughnut Pessary): Shape Circular or ring-shaped, with a central opening. Insertion Into the vagina. Indications Used for pelvic organ prolapse or urinary incontinence. Contraindications Active infections (PID, vaginitis) Latex sensitivity Noncompliant patient Complications Vaginal irritation/discomfort.

questions.question: A 45-year-old multiparous woman presents with a feeling of heaviness and something coming out of her vagina. She also has occasional lower back pain. On examination, there is a visible protrusion of a mass in the vaginal canal. Which of the following is the common complication associated with the condition?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C Explanation: Urinary incontinence is the most common complication associated with pelvic organ prolapse. Complications associated with pelvic organ prolapse: Complication Description Urinary incontinence (M/C) Loss of bladder control (stress incontinence). Urinary retention Difficulty in bladder emptying Recurrent urinary infections Due to incomplete bladder emptying. Bowel Dysfunction Constipation, straining, and faecal incontinence. Vaginal Ulceration Due to exposure and friction. Sexual Dysfunction Pain or discomfort during intercourse. Pelvic Pain Chronic pelvic pain, dyspareunia Gynaecological cancers, ovarian torsion and ovarian cysts have no direct association with uterine prolapse. Reference: Williams Gynaecology 4th Edition Pg: 542.

questions.question: A 54-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with urinary incontinence and heaviness in the pelvic area. Physical examination revealed a noticeable bulge protruding from her vagina. She has a history of uncontrolled diabetes and severe cardiovascular disease. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

options.C: Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B Explanation: Pessary insertion provides a non-surgical option for managing prolapse in patients unfit for surgery due to comorbidities. Pessary insertion: Relieves symptoms of prolapse by stretching the hiatus urogenitalis. Indications of Pessary use in prolapse: Early pregnancy up to 18 weeks Puerperium (facilitate involution) Unfit for surgical repair (old female with multiple co-morbidities) While waiting for surgical management. Complications of Pessary: Pessary ulcers: treated by local estrogen Vaginal bleeding Pelvic pain (with the use of larger pessaries) Vaginal discharge Pelvic floor exercises can help in the early stages of prolapse, but they are unlikely to be effective for this patient. Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair is not appropriate for a patient with multiple comorbidities that make her unfit for surgery. Sacrohysteropexy is indicated for managing prolapse in nulliparous females who want to retain the uterus. Reference: Williams Gynecology, 4th Edition, Pages 547-549. DC Dutta Textbook of Gynecology, 8th Edition, Page 176.

questions.question: In which of the following patients would Le Fort's repair be indicated?

options.A: Partial prolapse in a 35-year-old pregnant female
options.B: Complete prolapse in a 60-year-old female who has completed her family
options.C: Complete prolapse in a 65-year-old female with pelvic inflammatory disease
options.D: Complete prolapse in a 62-year-old female with a history of cervical cancer

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B Explanation: Le Fort's repair is a vaginal procedure (Obliteration of vaginal cavity used to treat complete uterine prolapse, particularly in older patients who have completed childbearing. Le Fort operation: Indication: Old age with procidentia when the patient is unfit for longer duration of surgeries (multiple co-morbidities). It involves partial closure of the vaginal canal to support the prolapsed uterus. Prerequisite: (Option D) Should not have any uterine or pelvic pathology (endometrial/cervical cancer). Cervical cytology (Pap smear) should be normal. Procedure: Stitch the anterior and posterior walls of the vagina. Performed under local anaesthesia. Complications: Pyometra, urinary stress incontinence. Contraindication: reproductive age group females Ring or gellhorn pessary is indicated in pregnant patients with prolapse. Severe pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is first treated with antibiotics. Le Fort's repair is not indicated for PID. Reference: Williams Gynecology, 4th Edition, Pages 1145-1149 DC Dutta Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page 183

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman who underwent a Fothergill repair for uterine prolapse five years ago presents with a history of recurrent second-trimester miscarriages. What is the most likely complication associated with her previous surgical procedure?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D Explanation: The Fothergill repair involves ligation of the round ligaments, which can cause cervical incompetence, resulting in repeated second-trimester losses and painless cervical dilatation. Fothergill repair/ Manchester repair: Indication: Preservation of reproductive function in patients with uterine prolapse Steps: Dilatation and curettage. Amputation of the cervix. Plication of the Mackenrodt’s (cardinal) ligaments. Anterior colporrhaphy and colpoperineorrhaphy. Complications: Cervical stenosis Fibrosis Cervical incompetence Urinary retention Uterine malformations, PID and antiphospholipid syndrome are causes of second-trimester pregnancy loss but are not typical complications of Fothergill’s procedure. Reference: DC Dutta Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition Pg:180-181

questions.question: A 27-year-old woman presents with complaints of vaginal bulge and increased pelvic pressure. On pelvic examination, the cervix is visible at the introitus. The patient desires for future childbearing. What is the management of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C Explanation: The management of a young woman with uterine prolapse who wishes to have children in the future needs to be managed with cervicopexy or sling surgery. Sling surgery (Cervicopexy): Management of uterocervical prolapse requiring future childbearing. Pre-requisite: should have a normal uterocervical length: Anterior sling surgery Posterior sling surgery Purandare sling Dynamic sling One side: isthmus of the uterus Other side: rectus sheath Low success rate Fewer complications Shirodkar sling Static sling One side: isthmus of the uterus Other side: Ligaments attached to the sacral promontory More complications: Intestinal obstruction (sigmoid colon) Genitofemoral nerve injury Mesenteric injury Note: Other sling surgeries: Composite/ virkud sling: Left side- Purandare, Right side- Shirodkar sling Khanna sling (anterior sling surgery): One side is the isthmus of the uterus, and the other side is the anterosuperior iliac spine. Ring pessary placement is a temporary cure suitable for older women who are unfit for surgery. Fothergill repair can be used for young women who do not intend to have children in the future. Colpocleisis involves closure of the vaginal canal, which is suitable for women >60year age with contraindications to surgery (such as diabetes). Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/8657402/#:~:text=Uterine%20prolapse%20can%20also%20occur,incl uding%20the%20possibility%20of%20childbearing . https://jogi.co.in/storage/files/13224_2020_1406_OnlinePDF.pdf DC Dutta Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition Pg:184

questions.question: Which of the following structures comprise DeLancey’s level 2 support?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C Explanation: Arcus tendinous fascia comprises level 2 DeLancey’s supports. DeLancey’s three levels of support: Structures Level I Uterosacral ligaments Cardinal ligaments Level II Arcus tendineus fascia Pubocervical fascia Rectovaginal fascia and septum Level III Perineal body Superficial and deep perineal muscles Fibromuscular connective tissue Reference: Williams Gynaecology Ed 4 Pg: 540,541 Shaws Gynaecology Ed 17 Pg: 286

questions.question: A 55-year-old woman presents with lower back pain and constipation for the last few weeks. Rectovaginal examination reveals a bulge felt in the posterior vaginal wall & felt on tip of the finger. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C Explanation: This patient's posterior vaginal bulge, back pain, and bowel movement difficulties are consistent with enterocele, which is characterised by the protrusion of the small intestine into the vaginal vault via the posterior vaginal wall. Enterocele (small bowel prolapse): Symptoms: Bulging sensation in the vagina. Lower back pain and pelvic discomfort increased during intercourse. Difficulty with bowel movements (constipation, feeling of incomplete evacuation) Rectovaginal examination: bulge (containing bowel loops) close to the cervix and cannot be reached by the finger inside the rectum Diagnosis: Dynamic MRI defecography Management: Conservative: kegel exercise, pessary. Surgical: Laparoscopic abdominal repair along with vaginal repair Rectocele is a prolapse of the rectum into the posterior vaginal wall, causing a bulge that can be reached by the finger on rectovaginal examination. Cystocele refers to the prolapse of the bladder into the anterior vaginal wall, leading to urinary symptoms. Relaxed perineum is weakening the perineal body due to an old scar of incomplete perineal tear. Reference: Williams Gynecology, Edition 4, Page 546, 552 Shaw Gynaecology, Edition 1, Page 298 DC Dutta Gynaecology, Edition 8, Page 174

questions.question: A 60-year-old woman presents with urinary incontinence and pelvic discomfort for last several weeks. She has to manually reposition the bulge to pass urine each time. There is no uterocervical descent.Which of the following is most suitable for surgical management for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A Explanation: Anterior colporrhaphy is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's cystocoele, which has a lower risk of complications. Cystocele: Clinical features Urinary incontinence Pelvic discomfort Anterior vaginal wall prolapse Bulge shows transverse rugosities and impulse on coughing Management Surgical: (recommended for women >40 years) Anterior Colporrhaphy: (most preferred) weakened tissue between the bladder and vagina is repaired. Mesh Repair: (Option B) synthetic mesh is used for additional support. Risk of recurrence, mesh erosion and infection Sacral Colpopexy: (Option C) Mesh is attached from the top of the vagina to the sacrum to lift the prolapsed organs. High risk of recurrence and complications Vaginal Hysterectomy: (Option D) Considered in cases where uterine prolapse coexists with cystocele. Conservative: Recommended in young women with prolapse following childbirth for initial 4-6 months Pelvic Floor Exercises Lifestyle modifications: avoid heavy lifting and constipation Pessary insertion (in patients unfit for surgery) Note: Surgical management is contraindicated during pregnancy. Reference: Williams Gynaecology, Edition 4, Page 552 Shaw Gynaecology, Edition17, Pages 293-294 DC Dutta Gynaecology, Edition 8, Page 173-174

questions.question: Which term describes the elongation of the supravaginal portion of the cervix?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C Explanation: Cervical elongation refers to the stretching or lengthening of the supravaginal portion of the cervix. It occurs due to the pull of cardinal ligaments (keep the cervix in position), whereas the weight of the uterus makes it fall through the vaginal axis. Chronic interference of venous and lymphatic drainage favours elongation. Management: Conservative : Pelvic floor exercises, lifestyle modifications and pessary insertion. Surgical: Cervical Cerclage (stitching the cervix) or hysterectomy (in severe cases). Reference: DC Dutta Gynaecology Ed 8 Pg:173

questions.question: On examination of a 60-year-old female with prolapse, the leading edge is more than 1 cm above the level of the hymen. Which stage of the POP-Q system does this finding correspond to?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B Explanation: Pelvic organ prolapse quantification (POP-Q) system: Stage Description Stage 0 (Option A) No prolapse. Stage I (Option B) The leading edge (most distal portion) of prolapse is more than 1 cm above the level of the hymen. Stage II (Option C) The leading edge of prolapse is ≤ 1 cm proximal or distal to the hymen. Stage III (Option B) The leading edge of the prolapse is more than 1 cm below the hymen but ≤ 2 cm less than the total vaginal length. Stage IV Essentially complete eversion of the total vaginal length.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a classification system used for uterine prolapse?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D Explanation : Lauren Classification system: used in gastric carcinoma (intestinal and diffuse type). Baden-Walker System assesses uterine prolapse by evaluating the degree of descent of the pelvic organs during a physical examination. Grade Degree of descent 0 Normal position for each respective site 1 Descent halfway to the hymen 2 Descent to the hymen 3 Descent halfway past the hymen 4 Maximum possible descent for each site Shaw Classification uses introitus as the reference point Rest all classifications including BADEN WALKER & Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification ( POP-Q ) - use hymen as the reference point Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5515689/#:~:text=The%20Laur%C3%A9n%20classification %20separates%20gastric,designated%20as%20mixed%2Dtype%20adenocarcinoma . https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3056425/

questions.question: A 58-year-old woman presents with a bulge in her vaginal area that worsens with standing for prolonged periods or straining. She has to push the bulge back into her vagina manually to relieve discomfort. Examination shows the following finding, uterine fundus lying outside the introitus with complete eversion of vaginal walls. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Procidentia Explanation: The image shows procidentia , characterized by prolapse of the uterus with complete eversion of the vagina. Degrees of Uterine Prolapse: First degree The uterus

questions.question: Match the following terms with their correct definitions. 1 Cystocele i The collapse of the upper 1/3rd of the posterior vaginal wall 2 Urethrocele ii The collapse of the upper 1/3rd of the anterior vaginal wall 3 Enterocele iii Laxity of the middle 1/3rd of the posterior vaginal wall 4 Rectocele iv The collapse of the lower 1/3rd of the anterior vaginal wall
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A Explanation: Cystocele The collapse of the upper 1/3rd of the anterior vaginal wall Urethrocele The collapse of the lower 1/3rd of the anterior vaginal wall Enterocele The collapse of the upper 1/3rd of the posterior vaginal wall Rectocele Laxity of the middle 1/3rd of the posterior vaginal wall and rectovaginal septum Types of genital prolapse:

questions.question: Which statement accurately describes the role of uterosacral and cardinal ligaments in preventing prolapse? downward pressures. prevent specific types of prolapse. pelvic landmarks, preventing various types of prolapse. wall and urethra to prevent prolapse.

options.A: They anchor the midvagina to pelvic structures, supporting the anterior and posterior vagina against
options.B: They support the lower part of the vagina and introitus, maintaining perineal muscle structure to
options.C: They suspend the upper vagina, maintain its length and position, and keep the cervix above specific
options.D: They connect the perineal body to muscles, helping to maintain the integrity of the anterior vaginal

questions.explanation: cervix above specific pelvic landmarks, preventing various types of prolapse. Correct answer: C Explanation: Function Damage Results Level I Suspends upper vagina Maintains vaginal length and horizontal axis Positions cervix above ischial spines Uterine descent Enterocele Vault descent Level II Attaches midvagina to arcus tendineus fascia pelvis (Option A) Provides lateral and apical anchor sites for anterior and posterior vagina Withstands downward pressures against the anterior vaginal wall and urethra Cystocele Rectocele Level III Supports distal one-third of the vagina and introitus (Options B & D) Urethrocele Gaping introitus Deficient perineum The uterosacral ligaments do contribute to preventing prolapse of the anterior vaginal wall, but they do not attach directly to the perineal body. Reference: Williams Gynaecology Ed 4 Pg: 540,541 Shaws Gynaecology Ed 17 Pg: 286

questions.question: Which of the following factors primarily causes uterine prolapse by directly damaging the pelvic support structures?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C Explanation: Causes of uterine prolapse: Predisposing Factors Aggravating Factors Other Factors Prolonged vaginal delivery (prolonged labour). Big baby. Menopause. Congenital weakness (Marfan’s syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome). Raised intra-abdominal pressure (e.g. COPD, constipation, obesity, etc). Increasing age. Multiparity. Smoking (Option D). Pelvic trauma. Perineal tear. Pudendal nerve injury. Spina bifida. Reference: Williams Gynaecology Ed 4 Pg: 536, 537 Shaw’s Gynaecology Ed 17 Pg: 287
